explanation: To decide whether any part of OS_FileSysMountVolume_Impl is statically or unconditionally unreachable you must know: (1) how the local pointer is obtained and whether OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET can fail or abort (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and OS_filesys_table); (2) the layout and types of the filesystem record (OS_filesys_internal_record_t and specifically its members system_mountpt and fstype) so you can reason about possible values and nullability; (3) the complete set/type of allowed fstype values (the enum/type OS_FileSysType and the specific constants OS_FILESYS_TYPE_VOLATILE_DISK and OS_FILESYS_TYPE_FS_BASED) to determine if the final if-condition can ever be true or is always false (which would make the OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED return unreachable); (4) the symbolic return values used by the function (OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED, OS_FS_ERR_DRIVE_NOT_CREATED, OS_SUCCESS) to identify distinct return points and whether any are unreachable; (5) the behavior and signatures of the POSIX calls and macros used at runtime (stat and struct stat, S_ISDIR, mkdir, strerror and errno) because these are runtime-dependent and demonstrate that branches (mkdir error path, non-directory path, successful stat path) are not compile-time constant — i.e., reachable depending on runtime; and (6) the logging macro (OS_DEBUG) only to check for side effects or expansions that might affect control flow. Each listed symbol is therefore necessary to determine whether any code path is impossible (unreachable) given the definitions and possible runtime/compile-time constraints.
